bestBHT.bht: The woman, being last in being, was first in sin—indeed, she alone was deceived. The present state of transgression in which the woman, by sin, is constituted, arose from her originally having been seduced by deceit. She more easily deceives due to her vulnerability to being deceived. The woman's subjection is regarded as a consequence of her being deceived. Adam, on the other hand, was not deceived and willingly partook in the transgression. This highlights the woman's susceptibility to deception and her role in influencing others to sin.

Henry Alford: As the woman was last in being, so she was first in sin."
The woman, having been seduced BY THE DECEIT, has become involved in transgression."
The present state of transgression in which the woman [and the man too: but that is not treated here] by sin is constituted, arose from her originally having been seduced by deceit.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: Being more easily deceived, she more easily deceives [BENGEL], (2 Corinthians 11:3)."
Last in being, she was first in sin—indeed, she alone was deceived.
Hence, as here, 1 Timothy 2:11, in 1 Timothy 2:11- :, woman's 'subjection' is represented as the consequence of her being deceived.
Albert Barnes: She had evinced a readiness to yield to temptation; a feebleness of resistance; a pliancy of character, which showed that she was not adapted to the situation of headship.
To tempt and seduce him to fall, there were needed all the soft persuasions, the entreaties, and example of his wife.

Sin, from the beginning, has been a process of delusion. Every man or woman who violates the law of God is deceived as to the happiness which is expected from the violation, and as to the consequences which will follow it.
Marvin Vincent: Was not deceived [ουκ ηπατηθη]. Once in Paul, Ephesians 5:6. Comp. 2 Corinthians 11:3. Rev. beguiled.
Being deceived [εξαπατηθεισα]. completely or thoroughly beguiled.
Was in the transgression [εν παραβασει γεγονεν]. Rend. hath fallen into transgression.
John Calvin: Because she had given fatal advice, it was right that she should learn that she was under the power and will of another.
The subjection of the woman is the punishment of her transgression, and yet it was imposed on her from the creation.
By these words Paul does not mean that Adam was not entangled by the same deceitfulness of the devil, but that the cause or source of the transgression proceeded from Eve.
Philip Schaff: The woman was in that first typical history the one directly deceived by the Tempter, Adam’s sin being thought of as more against light and knowledge,’ and so ‘she has come to be in the state of a transgressor.’
The implied thought, of course, is that that greater liability to deception continues now.
The history of the fall seemed to him acted over again.
Archibald T. Robertson: Not certain that εξ- here means 'completely deceived' in contrast to simplex (ουκ ηπατηθη) used of Adam, though possible.
Hath fallen (γεγονεν). Second perfect indicative active, permanent state.
John Gill: Adam never was deceived at all; neither by the serpent, with whom he never conversed; nor by his wife [...] he knew what he did, when he took the fruit and ate.

She really thought the serpent spoke truth [...] and under this deception she fell into the transgression, and was the cause and means, by her persuasions and example, of bringing her husband into the same sin.

Now inasmuch as the serpent did not attack Adam [...] and since not Adam, but Eve, was deceived, it appears that the man is the more proper person to bear rule and authority, as in civil and domestic, so in ecclesiastic affairs.
John Wesley: And Adam was not deceived — The serpent deceived Eve: Eve did not deceive Adam, but persuaded him."
The preceding verse showed why a woman should not 'usurp authority over the man.' this shows why she ought not 'to teach.'"
She is more easily deceived, and more easily deceives.

bhtAttempts.bht: The woman, being last in being, was first in sin. She was involved in transgression, having been deceived and seduced by the cunning of the serpent. This transgression and deceitfulness originated from her susceptibility to being deceived. The woman's subjection, as mentioned in 1 Timothy, is presented as a consequence of her deception. It is important to note that Adam was not deceived like Eve, but rather he knowingly partook in the sin. Therefore, the woman's role in the fall emphasizes her vulnerability to deception and her influence in deceiving others. This serves as a reminder of the consequences that arise from yielding to temptation and the importance of resisting deceptive influences.

The woman, being last in being, was first in sin. She was involved in transgression, having been deceived and seduced by the cunning of the serpent. This transgression and deceitfulness originated from her susceptibility to being deceived. The woman's subjection is presented as a consequence of her deception. It is important to note that Adam was not deceived like Eve, but rather he knowingly partook in the sin. Therefore, the woman's role in the fall emphasizes her vulnerability to deception and her influence in deceiving others.

The woman, being last in being, was first in sin—indeed, she alone was deceived. The present state of transgression in which the woman, by sin, is constituted, arose from her originally having been seduced by deceit. She more easily deceives due to her vulnerability to being deceived. The woman's subjection is regarded as a consequence of her being deceived. Adam, on the other hand, was not deceived and willingly partook in the transgression. This highlights the woman's susceptibility to deception and her role in influencing others to sin.

The woman, being last in being, was first in sin. She was involved in transgression, having been completely beguiled and deceived by the serpent. This deception led to her vulnerability to being deceived and her subsequent role in influencing others to sin. Unlike Eve, Adam was not deceived but knowingly partook in the sin. Therefore, the woman's susceptibility to deception emphasizes the consequences of yielding to temptation and the importance of resisting deceitful influences.

The woman, being last in being, was first in sin. She was involved in transgression, having been completely beguiled and deceived. This transgression and deceitfulness originated from her susceptibility to being completely or thoroughly beguiled. The woman's subjection is represented as the consequence of her being deceived. It is important to note that the man, Adam, was not deceived, unlike the woman. Therefore, the woman's vulnerability to deception emphasizes her influence in deceiving others through her persuasions and example, highlighting the need to resist deceptive influences.
